Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: The first step is understanding the typical Procure-to-Pay process: Create Purchase Requisition, Approve Purchase Requisition, Issue Purchase Order, Receive Goods, Receive Vendor Invoice, Match Invoice to PO, Release Payment, and Close Case. Any deviation from this typical flow is identified as an anomaly.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 1001 follows the correct sequence of events: Create, Approve, Issue PO, Receive Goods, Vendor Invoice Received, Match, Payment, Close. I concluded that there are no issues in this case.

Name: Pattern Recognition - IND
Text: Case 1002 has events that do not align with the typical order: a Purchase Order was issued before the requisition was approved, and payment was released before goods were received or the requisition was even approved.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The reasoning that issuing a PO before requisition approval and releasing payment before receiving goods or an invoice is anomalous was based on typical controls in procurement to mitigate financial risks.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: For Case 1003, I deduced that the out-of-sequence approval (payment released before invoice and goods) is most likely due to mismanagement or lack of adherence to controls, as standard operations wouldn't involve releasing a payment before confirming receipt of goods or services.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: In Case 1004, I identified the anomaly where goods were received before issuing a Purchase Order. I generated the hypothesis that this indicates unauthorized purchases or after-the-fact authorization of deliveries, which could lead to compliance or fraud risks.

Name: Validation - IND
Text: To confirm the anomalies in Case 1004, I cross-checked the standard flow (PO is issued before goods are received) against the event log sequence (Receive Goods before Issue PO). This validated my hypothesis for this case.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: I deduced that these anomalies across all three cases (1002, 1003, 1004) disrupt internal controls and increase risks such as errors, fraud, or financial loss. They bypass checks that are foundational to the Procure-to-Pay process.
